verses.kjv: And it came to pass, when Rehoboam had established the kingdom, and had strengthened himself, he forsook the law of the LORD, and all Israel with him.
verses.ct: Once Rehoboam had established his kingdom and consolidated his power, he abandoned the law of the LORD, and all Israel followed his example.

verses.kjv: And it came to pass, that in the fifth year of king Rehoboam Shishak king of Egypt came up against Jerusalem, because they had transgressed against the LORD,
verses.ct: In the 5th year of King Rehoboam's reign, King Shishak of Egypt marched against Jerusalem, because they had sinned against the LORD.

verses.kjv: With twelve hundred chariots, and threescore thousand horsemen: and the people were without number that came with him out of Egypt; the Lubims, the Sukkiims, and the Ethiopians.
verses.ct: He brought 1,200 chariots, 60,000 horsemen, and countless soldiers from Egypt — including Libyans, Sukkiims, and Ethiopians.

verses.kjv: And he took the fenced cities which pertained to Judah, and came to Jerusalem.
verses.ct: He captured the fortified cities of Judah and then advanced all the way to Jerusalem.

verses.kjv: Then came Shemaiah the prophet to Rehoboam, and to the princes of Judah, that were gathered together to Jerusalem because of Shishak, and said unto them, Thus saith the LORD, Ye have forsaken me, and therefore have I also left you in the hand of Shishak.
verses.ct: The prophet Shemaiah came to Rehoboam and the leaders of Judah who had gathered in Jerusalem because of Shishak, and told them, "This is what the LORD says: You have abandoned me, so I have handed you over to Shishak."

verses.kjv: Whereupon the princes of Israel and the king humbled themselves; and they said, The LORD is righteous.
verses.ct: At this, the leaders of Israel and the king humbled themselves and said, "The LORD is righteous."

verses.kjv: And when the LORD saw that they humbled themselves, the word of the LORD came to Shemaiah, saying, They have humbled themselves; therefore I will not destroy them, but I will grant them some deliverance; and my wrath shall not be poured out upon Jerusalem by the hand of Shishak.
verses.ct: When the LORD saw that they had humbled themselves, the LORD's message came to Shemaiah: "They have humbled themselves, so I will not destroy them. I will give them some measure of rescue, and my anger will not be unleashed on Jerusalem through Shishak."

verses.kjv: Nevertheless they shall be his servants; that they may know my service, and the service of the kingdoms of the countries.
verses.ct: "However, they will become his subjects, so that they learn the difference between serving me and serving the kingdoms of other nations."

verses.kjv: So Shishak king of Egypt came up against Jerusalem, and took away the treasures of the house of the LORD, and the treasures of the king’s house; he took all: he carried away also the shields of gold which Solomon had made.
verses.ct: So King Shishak of Egypt attacked Jerusalem and carried off the treasures from the LORD's temple and from the royal palace. He took everything, including the gold shields that Solomon had made.

verses.kjv: Instead of which king Rehoboam made shields of brass, and committed them to the hands of the chief of the guard, that kept the entrance of the king’s house.
verses.ct: King Rehoboam replaced them with bronze shields and entrusted them to the commanders of the royal guard who protected the entrance to the palace.

verses.kjv: And when the king entered into the house of the LORD, the guard came and fetched them, and brought them again into the guard chamber.
verses.ct: Whenever the king went to the LORD's temple, the guards would carry the shields and then return them to the guardroom afterward.

verses.kjv: And when he humbled himself, the wrath of the LORD turned from him, that he would not destroy him altogether: and also in Judah things went well.
verses.ct: Because Rehoboam humbled himself, the LORD's anger turned away from him, and God did not completely destroy him. In fact, conditions in Judah improved.

verses.kjv: So king Rehoboam strengthened himself in Jerusalem, and reigned: for Rehoboam was one and forty years old when he began to reign, and he reigned seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city which the LORD had chosen out of all the tribes of Israel, to put his name there. And his mother’s name was Naamah an Ammonitess.
verses.ct: King Rehoboam strengthened his position in Jerusalem and continued to rule. He was 41 years old when he became king, and he ruled for 17 years in Jerusalem — the city the LORD had chosen from all the tribes of Israel as the place to establish his name. His mother was Naamah, an Ammonite woman.

verses.kjv: And he did evil, because he prepared not his heart to seek the LORD.
verses.ct: He lived an evil life because he never committed his heart to seeking the LORD.

verses.kjv: Now the acts of Rehoboam, first and last, are they not written in the book of Shemaiah the prophet, and of Iddo the seer concerning genealogies? And there were wars between Rehoboam and Jeroboam continually.
verses.ct: Everything Rehoboam did, from beginning to end, is recorded in the writings of the prophet Shemaiah and of Iddo the seer, which include genealogical records. Rehoboam and Jeroboam were constantly at war with each other.

verses.kjv: And Rehoboam slept with his fathers, and was buried in the city of David: and Abijah his son reigned in his stead.
verses.ct: Rehoboam died and was buried in the City of David, and his son Abijah became king after him.
